journal-title-group.journal-title: Journal of autism and developmental disorders

title-group.article-title: Autism Symptoms across Adulthood in Men with Fragile X Syndrome: A Cross-sectional Analysis

contrib.aff: Human Development and Family Studies and Waisman Center, University of Wisconsin-Madison
Human Development and Family Studies, University of Wisconsin-Madison

author-notes.corresp: CORRESPONDING AUTHOR: Sigan L. Hartley, Human Development and Family Studies and Waisman Center, University of Wisconsin-Madison, 1500 Highland Ave., Madison, WI 5705, (608)265-5424., hartley@waisman.wisc.edu

abstract.p: A cross-sectional analysis was used to examine age-related differences in ASD symptoms and corresponding differences in disruptive behavior and social skills in 281 adult men with Fragile X syndrome (FXS). Four age groups were created: 18–21 years, 22–29 years, 30–39 years, and 40–49 years. The 18–21 year-old group was reported to have more impairments in verbal communication than the 22–29 year-old group and more restricted and repetitive behaviors than the 40–49 year-old group. There was not an age-group difference in the percentage of men who met criteria for an ASD diagnosis based on respondent-reported, current symptoms. There was a trend for an age-related difference in disruptive behavior. Findings add to understanding of the developmental trajectory of ASD symptoms in adulthood.
